perturbation.original_text: Each Party agrees to obtain and maintain, during the Term and for five (5) years after the Term, commercial general liability insurance, including products liability insurance, with minimum "A-" AM Best rated insurance carriers, in each case with limits of not less than five million dollars ($5,000,000) per occurrence and in the aggregate. All deductibles/retentions will be the responsibility of the named insured. Pfizer and its Affiliates will be an additional insured on Exact's commercial general liability and products liability policies, and be provided with a waiver of subrogation. To the extent of its culpability, all coverages of Exact will be primary and non-contributing with any similar insurance carried by Pfizer. Notwithstanding any provision of this Section 6.2 to the contrary, Pfizer may meet its obligations under this Section 6.2 through self-insurance.
perturbation.changed_text: Each Party agrees to obtain and maintain, during the Term, commercial general liability insurance, including products liability insurance. All deductibles/retentions will be the responsibility of the named insured. Notwithstanding any provision of this Section 6.2 to the contrary, Pfizer may meet its obligations under this Section 6.2 through self-insurance.
perturbation.explanation: By removing the minimum rating requirement ('A-' AM Best rated insurance carriers'), the specific coverage limits (five million dollars per occurrence and in the aggregate), the additional insured status for Pfizer, the waiver of subrogation, the provision ensuring Exact's coverage is primary, and the coverage after the term, the contract introduces a significant loophole. This could violate standard business practice and potentially state laws requiring specific insurance coverage in commercial contracts. Removing the obligation to maintain insurance coverage for five years after the term could violate state laws regarding liability for products sold during the term but causing harm afterward. These omissions create legal risk.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Breach of contract, violation of state laws regarding commercial insurance requirements and product liability.

perturbation.explanation: By omitting 'Applicable Laws (including the FD&C Act, the Anti-Kickback Statute (42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b), Civil Monetary Penalty Statute (42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7a), the False Claims Act (31 U.S.C. § 3729 et seq.), comparable state statutes, the regulations promulgated under all such statutes, and the regulations issued by the FDA)', the contract provides a loophole. This potentially contradicts federal and state laws that mandate compliance with healthcare regulations, which could open the parties involved to legal action.
perturbation.contradicted_law: The FD&C Act, the Anti-Kickback Statute (42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7b), Civil Monetary Penalty Statute (42 U.S.C. § 1320a-7a), the False Claims Act (31 U.S.C. § 3729 et seq.)
